MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Sligo Regional Technical College.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the fact that (a) the library in Sligo Regional Technical College with approximately 90 seats for 1,300 students is totally inadequate in size (b) the library is also completely understaffed with a ratio of one staff member to each 500 students (c) Sligo Regional Technical College is unable to shelve books purchased because of lack of shelf space, lack of staff time to reshelve, and lack of any security system in the library (d) next year the college will be forced to spend the full library budget of £14,000 on purchasing a security system as opposed to the purchase of up-to-date books (e) the library lacks adequate emergency exits and (f) this problem can only be addressed by the building of a new library, provision of adequate staff and provision of an increased budget for library expenditure; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

if her attention has been drawn to the fact that (a) first and third year art and design students of Sligo Regional Technical College do not study in the main college but in accommodation in Quay Street, Sligo, a considerable distance away (b) there is total lack of adequate space for students in Quay Street with overcrowding in the classrooms and no auxiliary space (c) students have complained of the classrooms being draughty and cold during the day and (d) in order to avail of library facilities these 80 students have to come to the main college building which is 25 minutes' walk away; if she intends to make any provision to have this situation alleviated; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 260 and 261 together.

MainHeading.P: My Department are aware of the situation in Sligo Regional Technical College and have been in touch with the college authorities as is normally the case. There are plans for the improvement of library facilities in the college and it is hoped to make progress on the matter shortly. There are no plans for accommodating students at present in the premises at Quay Street in the main part of the college, but I would hope that as finance becomes available improvements would be made in the Quay Street premises.
In relation to current work in the regional technical college, improvements have been made to the canteen and an extension to cater for the National Toolmaking Centre is in hands.
My Department have recently sanctioned an additional library assistant to Sligo Regional Technical College bringing the current library staff to one assistant librarian and three library assistants.

The position with regard to library staffing in the colleges in general is under consideration at present. I propose to engage in further consultation on the matter with a view to getting agreement on an appropriate structure. It is hoped also to address the question of general library expenditure.

Qst.Quest: if it is intended to continue the course in industrial design in Sligo Regional Technical College which was introduced into the college in 1989; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
if it is intended to extend the marketing and languages diploma course at Sligo Regional Technical College to a degree course; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

if her attention has been drawn to the fact that students and staff in the social studies course in Sligo Regional Technical College are keen to have the college offer a diploma as well as a certificate in social studies and that the college applied last year for such a course; and if she will outline the present position.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 262, 263 and 264 together.

MainHeading.P: The establishment and continuation of courses in regional technical colleges is a matter in the first instance for individual college managements having regard to the requirements of the course validating agency. All new courses require the prior approval of my Department.

No proposals for the initiation of a degree course in marketing and languages or a diploma course in social studies have been received in my Department to date. I understand also that the college management proposes to continue the course in industrial design.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - ESF Students Grants.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the many anomalies caused by the 15 mile rule covering students attending regional technical colleges and in receipt of ESF grants; if she intends to introduce any degree of flexibility into the 15 mile rule; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The ESF training grants scheme covers a series of full time vocational training courses of up to three years duration in regional technical colleges and colleges of technology. Trainees are entitled to tuition fee remission and a monthly maintenance allowance currently valued at £547 or £1,373 per annum depending on whether or not they must reside away from home in a college town.

The regulations governing the ESF scheme stipulate that the lower rate of grant is applicable in the case of trainees, (a) whose home is within 15 miles of the college attended, (b) who travel, or could reasonably be expected to travel, daily between their home and the college. The regulations further stipulate that the higher rate may be paid only to those not covered by (a) and (b) above who are obliged to stay overnight in a college town for the purpose of attending a training course.

MainHeading.P: The 15 mile rule is considered reasonable. The Deputy will appreciate that administrative regulations must apply to the scheme to facilitate its smooth operation and any set of such regulations will almost always create difficulties for certain individual cases.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Higher Education Grants Scheme.

Qst.Quest: if she intends to make the changes in qualifying standards for third level college grants retrospective to cover all students currently pursuing third level courses; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the cost of making retrospective, to include those who passed the leaving certificate in previous years, the new arrangement whereby the academic requirement for higher education grants has been reduced from four honours to two honours; and if she is prepared to make this concession retrospective.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 266 and 269 together.

I was very pleased to have been in a position to remove the long standing anomaly in the higher education grants scheme by allowing students with two honours in the 1990 leaving certificate who secure a place on an approved third level course to be eligible for a higher education grant subject to satisfying the other requirements re. means, residence, etc.

The revised two honours rule will apply only in respect of leaving certificate results in 1990 and subsequent years. Students with leaving certificate successes prior to 1990 will be subject to the terms of the higher education grants scheme of the year in which they secured the leaving certificate successes. In accordance with normal practice the improvements in the higher education grants scheme made for the 1990-91 academic year are applicable from a current date.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if she will outline the appropriate action which should be taken by a teacher who suspects that one of his or her pupils has been the victim of abuse at home; and the legal protection, if any, which her Department are prepared to give a teacher who takes the recommended action.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if she has received an application for support and official recognition for the European Children's Inter-School Project Programme, prepared by a person (details supplied); if her attention has been drawn to the fact that this project is consistent with moves in other countries towards European studies in schools and inter-action between schools in different parts of the European Community; and if she is prepared to have this project supported as a pilot scheme or otherwise.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I have received the application for support for a project entitled “European Children's Inter-School Project”.

My Department is already giving financial and pedagogical support to a European Studies Project involving primarily schools in this State, Northern Ireland and England and also schools in Belgium, France and Germany. The ages of the pupils involved in this project range from 11 to 18 years. This project is due to terminate in September, 1992 and I have arranged for a detailed evaluation of this project in conjunction with the other education authorities involved.

The proposal for the project referred to in the question has many similarities with the existing pilot project and I do not propose to commit any further funds to this area until I have the evaluation of the European Studies Project to hand.
The proposer has been informed that my Department is not in a position to support his proposal for a European Children's Inter-School Project Programme in the present circumstances.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Post-Leaving Certificate Courses.

Qst.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Qst.Quest: in respect of post leaving certificate courses (a) the number of students who enrol in such courses, (b) whether her Department is involved in sanctioning and/or monitoring such courses and (c) her plans to undertake the necessary certification of such courses.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: 11,434 trainees participated in Vocational Preparation and Training VPT-2 courses in 1989-90. VPT-2 is aimed at trainees who have either completed a senior cycle programme or a VPT-1 course but who need further training to enhance their prospects of securing lasting employment.

MainHeading.P: Participation by schools in the programme is subject to approval annually by my Department, and programme delivery is monitored on an on-going basis. At present each trainee who successfully completes the programme is awarded a certificate by my Department which is supplemented by locally based assessment certification. However, there is a need for a national, performance based certification system.

A working group will report to me shortly on the general question of assessment and certification of second level vocational training programmes with a view to the establishment of such a national system.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - International Literacy Year.

Qst.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Qst.Quest: if she will outline the events/projects undertaken by, or with the assistance of, her Department to mark International Literacy Year, 1990 in Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I was very pleased, as an exceptional measure, to double the special fund for the adult literacy and community education scheme in 1990.
The following are activities undertaken by my Department or with the assistance of my Department to mark the International Literacy Year, 1990:

—Increased activities by the vocational education committees arising from additional funding for the adult literacy and community education scheme, the targeting of those funds for the disadvantaged, the issue of new guidelines giving priority to literacy and enhanced monitoring and evaluation of the scheme.

—Expanded programme by the National Adult Literacy Agency arising from increased funding, including a formal launch of the International Literacy Year and the organising of a seminar to mark the International Literacy Day and many other related activities undertaken by the agency.
—Activities arising from funding provided for the Dublin Institute for Adult Education, the Reading Association of Ireland and the Association for the Adult Education of Travellers.

MainHeading.P: —Provision of reading materials for travelling children.
—Provision of literacy materials in Irish for Gaeltacht areas.
—Special in-service courses for teachers.
—A special £1 million extra for schools library service.

I now intend to have a series of meetings with all of the relevant bodies associated with the work of International Literacy Year to evaluate the progress made to build upon the work undertaken and to plan for the future.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Virginia (Cavan) School Pupil-Teacher Ratio.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the fact that there are 35 children in second and third class in St. Mary's national school, Virginia, County Cavan; her views on whether this situation is unsatisfactory; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will be aware there is an agreement between the Government and the INTO regarding the staffing of national schools.

As part of this agreement my Department have implemented a reduction of one unit in the enrolment-staffing schedule for national schools from 1 September 1990. This agreement has led to an improvement in the pupil-teacher ratio in national schools for the 1990-91 school year.

Under existing arrangements negotiated under the auspices of the Central Review Committee, school authorities, in particular the principal teacher, are responsible for arranging the organisation of the school so as to ensure that no class group exceeds the following guidelines set down by my Department; 39 (in the case of a single-grade class-group); 38 (in the case of a class-group with two consecutive grades); and 35 (in the case of a multi-grade class-group).
There is no class in breach of the Department's guidelines on maximum class size.
The enrolment in the school on 30 September 1990 was 196. Staff consists of a principal and five assistants, giving average class size approximately of 33.
The issue of class sizes in national schools will be reviewed in the context of ongoing discussions on the programme for economic and social development.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Primary Curriculum Report.

Qst.Quest: the arrangements she intends to put in place to implement the recommendations contained in the Report of the Review Body on the Primary Curriculum; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Following the presentation of the report to me I asked the National Council for Curriculum and Assessment to undertake the task of disseminating the report as widely as possible and of seeking the views and observations of all interested parties on the report's recommendations. The views expressed by interested parties on the recommendations of the report are being analysed by the council and I expect to receive a report on the outcome of that analysis soon.

An examination of the report by my Department will be co-ordinated with the views submitted through the National Council for Curriculum and Assessment and co-related with consideration of the findings of the reports of the Primary Education Review Body and the OECD which are to be published shortly.
The results of the above process will be included in proposals by my Department for a comprehensive plan for the development of primary education.

The report on the curriculum identifies specific areas for action. On receiving the report I indicated my own commitment to use the report as a basis for action. I requested the National Council for Curriculum and Assessment to co-ordinate the next stage of implementation.
The action points to be undertaken immediately are set out as follows:

MainHeading.P: —copies of the report together with summary bulletins to be widely disseminated: June to September 1990;
—a process of formal and informal consultation and discussion to be carried out through seminars and other activities, summer/autumn 1990;
—responses to the report should be submitted to the chief executive, NCCA, by mid-November 1990;
—responses of the teaching profession and of the public to the recommendations of the report to be summarised, November 1990.

This should lead to consultations with the major interests at primary level on the details of an implementation strategy. Such a strategy might include structures for the development of the curriculum and, also, an approach to the overall implementation of the recommendations of the report.
